80% detections smaller than 0.5. Really difficult to get exact min time here because they don't really report that. 6 comes from S1 revisit period, and a very short paragraph addresses this just before Section 5.3. Median time is taken as mean of first two cols of Fig 7 for core pixels (62 and 42%). 365 chosen as upper bound based on subjective interpretation of fig 9 for this plot. The F1 score is taken as reported from Section 5.1, while the time is not as straightforward. The paper presents the latency as 126 days for confirming 50% of disturbances, but in order to more directly compare with our study, we used the minimum latency for which most pixels had > 50% probability of infestation.
timelag is given as months, so here it's 0.22 months is the min, which equals 6.6 days. Timelag reported as "mean time lag"

Paper was more focused on accuracy of neural network than detection timing. Min time here is because authors only used 1 image every 12 days. Accuracy is reported F1 score for 2019 dataset in Results.

A spectrum of results were presented in this paper, similar to ours. To use a single latency and accuracy metric to be comparable to our method, we used the initial lag and accuracy from the P1 configuration (low algorithm lag) for an event spatial unit (Table 2), which yielded the reported metrics of 10 days latency and 0.069 F1 score.

reported as 12 days for confirmed dist; max size is reported as >=20 ha. We used the overall accuracy reported for all types of deforestation (“Global”) for SAR data (FA1; Table 2) to show the highest accuracy obtained. The reported latency is from Section 4.2 and is taken as the mean algorithm detection delay.
